facts.text: Appellant and six other persons charged under ss. 4 and 5 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act 1887.
Sub-inspector of police Shri Anjaria received information that the appellant was keeping a common gaming house.
Shri Anjaria obtained a special search warrant from the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Porbandar, Shri S. M. Pandya.
Raiding party raided the appellant's house in Bantwa on June 4, 1961 at 1 p.m.
Door leading to the upper floor closed; inmates pressed against the door from inside and did not open it until blacksmith broke open the latch.

Seized: torn and burnt pieces of playing cards lying on the floor of the central room, two packs of cards from a wall cabinet, some burnt cards lying on the floor and in the folds of a bed in the drawing room, four jokers and three packs of cards from trunks in the kitchen, some cash, burnt cigarette ends, bidis and matches and empty cigarette cases.
All the accused were found in the upper floor.
Appellant as the occupant of the house charged under s. 4 of the Act; other six accused charged under s. 5 of the Act.
Learned magistrate refused to raise presumption under s. 7 on ground that Shri Pandya not specially empowered by name to issue search warrant; acquitted all accused.
On appeal, Gujarat High Court held Shri Pandya as deputy superintendent specially empowered; prosecution entitled to presumption under s. 7.

High Court convicted appellant under s. 4 and sentenced to simple imprisonment for one month; convicted other six under s. 5 and sentenced each to fine of Rs. 200, in default simple imprisonment for one month.
Present appeal filed by appellant by special leave.

Notification dated January 22, 1955 by Saurashtra government specially empowered certain assistant and deputy superintendents including deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar Division, to issue special warrants.
Notification continued in force after merger of Saurashtra with State of Bombay.
Appellant could not rebut presumption under s. 7; resistance to entry and attempt to burn/destroy/conceal cards fortified presumption.
Appellant's explanation of inviting friends/relatives for son's betrothal not convincing.

legal_issues.text: Whether a Deputy Superintendent of Police specially empowered by virtue of office (and not by name) can issue a search warrant under s. 6 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act 1887.
Whether presumption under s. 7 applies and was rebutted.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s. 6, officer must be specially empowered by name (relying on Emperor v. Udho). Notification empowering DSP Porbandar insufficient.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act s.6; Emperor v. Udho

petitioner_arguments.text: Search warrant invalid as it did not ex facie set out authority.
Explanation: invited friends for son's betrothal; cards for innocent pastime.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act s.7

respondent_arguments.text: DSP Porbandar specially empowered by virtue of office (relying on Emperor v. Savlaram Kashinath Joshi).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act s.6; Emperor v. Savlaram Kashinath Joshi

court_reasoning.text: S.15 Bombay General Clauses Act allows appointment by name or virtue of office. Person may be empowered by name or by office.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Where power conferred on person by name or by virtue of office, individual designated is specially empowered.

court_reasoning.text: Emperor v. Udho incorrect; Emperor v. Savlaram correctly held notification empowers holder of office.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notification dated 22.1.1955 specially empowered Shri Pandya as DSP Porbandar.

court_reasoning.text: Seizure under s.6 raises presumption u/s.7; apply with circumspection but appellant failed to rebut.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Resistance to entry and destruction of cards fortify presumption; betrothal explanation unconvincing.

court_reasoning.text: No prejudice by producing notification at appellate stage; new point on warrant not allowed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court rightly convicted appellant under s.4.

holdings.text: Deputy Superintendent of Police specially empowered by virtue of office under notification can issue search warrant u/s.6.
Presumption u/s.7 not rebutted; house used as common gaming house.

precedents_cited.relevance: Interpreted 'specially empowered' as by name only; court holds incorrect.
Held officer empowered by virtue of office under s.6.
Authorization of magistrate by office is special empowering.

statutes_cited.relevance: Charges under ss.4,5; search warrant and presumption under ss.6,7.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court conviction of appellant under s.4 Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act, holding DSP specially empowered by office to issue warrant and presumption u/s.7 not rebutted. No interference with findings.

key_quotes.text: "A person may be specially empowered not only by name but also by virtue of his office."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of 'specially empowered' under s.6.

key_quotes.text: "Judged by this test, the notification dated January 22, 1955, specially empowered Shri Pandya as the holder of the office of the deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar, to issue the search warrant under s. 6."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applies test to facts, resolves key issue.

key_quotes.text: "The resistance to the entry of the sub inspector and the attempt to burn, destroy and conceal the playing cards fortified the presumption."
key_quotes.speaker: court
